div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 23, 1876
div1.p:
After the
day's work was done, yes-
terday, I thought that I could
spend the concluding hours
of the day in no better or
more pleasant way than
by writing to the dear lit-
tle girl who had been so
good as to write me such
a long letter- Albeit, it was
Wednesday, & notwithstanding
the fact that I knew you
would not care a penny
for any letter that was
not written on either Mon-
day or Thursday, still I thought,
to write to my little love, would
be a fitting termination to
the day- And indeed, I believe
that I should have written
had not the reason, which
I have just stated, been
present in my mind, and,
of course, I couldn't think
of violating my little Em-
ilie's wishes- Ah! You can't
imagine what a splendid
piece of composition you missed! One of
the old kind- like those
long, sixteen-page letters
that I used to write
when you were a little
girl, just graduated from
College! I can but draw
a sigh, of the very deepest,
when I think of the num-
ber of bright things I was
going to say & the number
of sweet expressions I
had at my pen's end; ready
to submit them, one & all,
for your consideration: but
they are gone now- Yes,
fled forever & may never
return, & whereas, had they
been written down, e're
they took their immortal
(excuse me, for using the ex-
pression, but no other will
do justice) flight, I might
have expired happy, know-
ing how great a monument
I had erected, now I must
perish ignobly! Do you
blame me for being sad?
But I will suppress my
sorrow & disappointment-
and not even you shall
know the depths of my grief!
All that I can ask of you
is that you will accept what
I have written with the
customary margin that is
due all of my expressions, and
I think I can still find
some happiness “here
below”! whether I find hap-
piness or not, I have certain-
ly struck a mine of work-
“Busy”! why that is the fee-
blest word that can possi-
bly be applied to my pres-
ent condition- If I was
ever idle, I do not regret it
now, for I have enough
to do to atone for all my
past laziness. The only con-
solation I have, is that it
must soon be over & then
I will have a long re-
spite. I must confess
that your allusion to some
compliment, that I had been
paid me by one of the fair
sex, raised my curiosity
to no ordinary pitch of ex-
citement- That the effect
would have been otherwise,
could not have been expec-
ted- Remember my well-
known conceit & that a
compliment from a lady
is a rare occurrence in
my life- Can't recall but
two- One you would not
disclose, which I thought
and still think, was very
cruel, on your part, & the
other contained in your last
letter- In vain have I racked
my brain to find out who
the lady is that has been so
very kind as to furnish me
a good topic to write about-
It was so considerate in
her to do so- I almost am
led to think that the lady
is named miss Emilie, &
would be convinced of the
fact, did I not know her mod-
esty is too great for such
a compliment- Since it is
not you, my darling, I am
willing to bet my high hat
that the fair one is a mrs., &
not a miss! Come! will you
take the offer? Ah! my
precious little girl, do you think that
I am so innocent? Alas! always select
me to solve a problem! you will never
regret it. As for Miss Peace, who complains
of my neglect, I've nought to say; although
I would that I could avail myself of your
offer to come again & remain a week-
I wouldn't promise, however, that I would
call on Miss Peace, for when I visit Mur-
freesboro, it is for the sole purpose of seeing
my darling, sweet Emilie, & no other man, woman
or child in this wide, wide world! So much for Miss P.
Finger is quite well-
